CONJUGATES: rumours (n.pl.) | rumours (v. 3rd sg. pres.) | rumoured (v. past simple, past participle) | rumouring (v. present participle)
ETYMOLOGY: From Old French rumor (modern French rumeur), from Latin rūmor ('noise, outcry, common talk, hearsay').

MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A currently circulating story or report of uncertain or doubtful truth; gossip.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 未经证实而在人群中流传的故事或消息；谣言。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: There's a rumour that they are planning to move to another city.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 有谣言说他们计划搬到另一个城市。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: transitive verb (takes a direct object) | intransitive verb (does not take a direct object)
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: To spread a rumour or tell a story that may not be true; to be circulated as a rumour.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 散布谣言；传闻；（消息）被传开。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: He was rumoured to have resigned after the scandal.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 据传闻，他在丑闻发生后辞职了。
